repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
e.g. with the allocator specified, or with a hash function or predicate etc. It needs to generate a separate version of the conversion code for each variation of the container.

Fixes #4166

comment_data.body:
It's interesting that the style checker didn't complain here (also in the other places that use `…+…`).
```suggestion
                optional_arg_template_names = "," + optional_arg_template_names
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3787,24 +3787,39 @@ def create_from_py_utility_code(self, env):
             X = "XYZABC"
             tags = []
             context = {}
+            optional_tags = []
+            optional_tag_strs = []
+            optional_arg_template_names = []  # these may be different (e.g. for unordered_map, map)
+                # hence have to be generated here rather than hard-coded in the utility_code
             for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
                 if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
-                    break
+                    optional_arg_template_names.append("%s=*" % self.template_type.templates[ix].name)
+                    if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                        optional_tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                        optional_tag_strs.append(X[ix])
+                        context[X[ix]] = T
+                    continue
                 if T.is_pyobject or not T.create_from_py_utility_code(env):
                     return False
                 tags.append(T.specialization_name())
                 context[X[ix]] = T
 
             if self.cname in cpp_string_conversions:
                 cls = 'string'
-                tags = type_identifier(self),
+                tags = [type_identifier(self)]
             else:
                 cls = self.cname[5:]
-            cname = '__pyx_convert_%s_from_py_%s' % (cls, '__and_'.join(tags))
+            optional_tag_strs = ",".join(optional_tag_strs)
+            optional_arg_template_names = ",".join(optional_arg_template_names)
+            if optional_arg_template_names:
+                optional_arg_template_names = ","+optional_arg_template_names

comment_data.body: (Ah, I know – we have stuff like `n+1` in the code base, without whitespace, which is … ok, but rules out enabling the code style checks for arithmetic operators. Too bad…)

comment_data.body:
This casting away the const feels slightly dubious to me.

It's because Cython infers the iterator type from `begin`, I wonder if it should try `const_begin` first for const types, but that feels like a separate change.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -136,34 +103,22 @@ cdef object {{cname}}(const cpp_list[X]& v):
 
 #################### set.from_py ####################
 
-cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass set "std::{{maybe_unordered}}set" [T]:
-        void insert(T&) except +
-
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef set[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
-    cdef set[X] s
+cdef Tp {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+    cdef Tp s
     for item in o:
-        s.insert(<X>item)
+        s.insert(<Tp.value_type>item)
     return s
 
 
 #################### set.to_py ####################
 
 cimport cython
 
-cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass cpp_set "std::{{maybe_unordered}}set" [T]:
-        cppclass const_iterator:
-            T& operator*()
-            const_iterator operator++()
-            bint operator!=(const_iterator)
-        const_iterator begin()
-        const_iterator end()
-
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef object {{cname}}(const cpp_set[X]& s):
-    return {v for v in s}
+cdef object {{cname}}(const Tp& s):
+    # casting away the const is a bit dubious, but helps Cython do the iteration
+    return {v for v in <Tp&>s}

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                # not all template types are convertible
                return None
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3780,31 +3780,39 @@ def can_coerce_from_pyobject(self, env):
             return True
         return False
 
+    def _get_conversion_tags_context_cls(self, env, tags, context):
+        # modifies tags and context, returns the cls name or False (if it's not convertible)
+        for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
+            if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
+                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                continue
+            if not T.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+                return False

comment_data.body: The method is called `_get_…` but changes its input arguments. That seems fishy. There's more than one function in here, I'd say.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3780,31 +3780,39 @@ def can_coerce_from_pyobject(self, env):
             return True
         return False
 
+    def _get_conversion_tags_context_cls(self, env, tags, context):
+        # modifies tags and context, returns the cls name or False (if it's not convertible)
+        for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
+            if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
+                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                continue
+            if not T.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+                return False
+            tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+
+        context['Tp'] = self

comment_data.body:
Possibly this should be split into a validation function that just does

```
<loop>:
    if not T.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
        return False
```

and a tag/context/cname generation function that does the rest. Which is possibly what you meant by:

> ISTM that the loop over the templates is really two separate loops, for example.

I'll wait to see how much this change breaks first though
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3780,31 +3780,39 @@ def can_coerce_from_pyobject(self, env):
             return True
         return False
 
+    def _get_conversion_tags_context_cls(self, env, tags, context):
+        # modifies tags and context, returns the cls name or False (if it's not convertible)
+        for ix, T in enumerate(self.templates or []):
+            if ix >= builtin_cpp_conversions[self.cname]:
+                if not isinstance(T, TemplatePlaceholderType):
+                    tags.append(T.specialization_name())
+                continue
+            if not T.create_to_py_utility_code(env):
+                return False
+            tags.append(T.specialization_name())

comment_data.body: Did you really mean to use `Tp` as a type name here? Does that work?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,66 +4,47 @@
 #################### string.from_py ####################
 
 cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass string "{{type}}":
-        string() except +
-        string(char* c_str, size_t size) except +
     cdef const char* __Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize(object, Py_ssize_t*) except NULL
 
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef string {{cname}}(object o) except *:
+cdef Tp {{cname}}(object o) except *:
     cdef Py_ssize_t length = 0
     cdef const char* data = __Pyx_PyObject_AsStringAndSize(o, &length)
-    return string(data, length)
+    return Tp(data, length)
 
 
 #################### string.to_py ####################
 
-#cimport cython
-#from libcpp.string cimport string
-cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass string "{{type}}":
-        char* data()
-        size_t size()
-
 {{for py_type in ['PyObject', 'PyUnicode', 'PyStr', 'PyBytes', 'PyByteArray']}}
 cdef extern from *:
     cdef object __Pyx_{{py_type}}_FromStringAndSize(const char*, size_t)
 
 @cname("{{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}")
-cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const string& s):
+cdef inline object {{cname.replace("PyObject", py_type, 1)}}(const Tp& s):
     return __Pyx_{{py_type}}_FromStringAndSize(s.data(), s.size())
 {{endfor}}
 
 
 #################### vector.from_py ####################
 
-cdef extern from *:
-    cdef cppclass vector "std::vector" [T]:
-        void push_back(T&) except +
-
 @cname("{{cname}}")
-cdef vector[X] {{cname}}(object o) except *:
-    cdef vector[X] v
+cdef Tp {{cname}}(object o) except *:

comment_data.body: Yes it seems to work. It's extracted from the context in exactly the same way that `X` used to be.

commit.message:
Conversion of C++ containers with optional templates

e.g. with the allocator specified, or with a hash function or
predicate etc. It needs to generate a separate version of the
conversion code for each variation of the container.

Fixes #4166
Use converted type directly rather than redeclaring it

title: Conversion of C++ containers with optional templates
